title: Microcosm-dependent degradation of nonwoven fabric in surgical masks by endophytic fungi Aspergillus bridgerii
source: ScienceDirect Publication: Journal of Hazardous Materials
excerpt: Publication date: 15 February 2026Source: Journal of Hazardous Materials, Volume 504Author(s): Ramya Duraisamy, Bhuvaneshwari. S, Philip. A, VM Vishnu, P. Sribalaji, Agnieszka Saeid, Jemima Balaselvi Juliana. S, Jennifer Michellin Kiruba N
summary: In the Anthropocene, multispecies assemblages interact with industrial materials in unpredictable ways. Aspergillus bridgerii, an endophytic fungus, has been observed to degrade nonwoven fabric in surgical masks, which are designed to filter out airborne pathogens. This degradation is facilitated by the fungus's ability to break down polypropylene, a common material used in mask production. The breakdown of masks can lead to the release of microplastics and other pollutants into the environment, further exacerbating ecosystem disruption. The degradation of masks by Aspergillus bridgerii highlights the complex, often unanticipated interactions between human infrastructure and nonhuman life forms in the Anthropocene.

title: Toxicological interactions between biotic and abiotic components of indoor air: Mold and air fresheners
source: ScienceDirect Publication: Journal of Hazardous Materials
excerpt: Publication date: 15 February 2026Source: Journal of Hazardous Materials, Volume 504Author(s): Sudheer Salana, Avraham Moshe Friedman, Jess Austin, Preyasha Shrestha, Kiran Kurmi, Mohammad Washeem, Chang-Yu Wu
summary: Mold colonization in urban environments has been observed to rapidly proliferate on indoor surfaces treated with air fresheners. In one study, Trichoderma reesei mold species demonstrated increased growth rates on surfaces coated with synthetic fragrances, such as diethyl phthalate and limonene. Biochemical analysis revealed that these compounds altered the mold's secondary metabolism, increasing the production of mycotoxins and volatile organic compounds (VOCs). The resultant indoor air environment exhibited synergistic interactions between mold and air freshener emissions, amplifying the concentration of noxious VOCs and particulate matter. In such assemblages, multispecies interactions transcend human design, yielding unexpected toxicological outcomes that pose risks to human and nonhuman inhabitants alike.

title: Antifungal mechanism and mycotoxin control of Ligusticum jeholense essential oil against Alternaria alternata in postharvest tomato
excerpt: Publication date: 1 April 2026Source: Food Chemistry, Volume 507Author(s): Quan-Shui Wang, Sen Pang, Xiao-Yi Tong, Du-Qiang Luo, Jian Wang, Fei Cao
summary: Invasive and opportunistic fungal species such as Alternaria alternata exploit human infrastructure, threatening food security and ecosystems. Research on Ligusticum jeholense essential oil reveals a potent antifungal mechanism against Alternaria alternata, reducing mycotoxin production and decay in postharvest tomatoes. The essential oil's mode of action involves the disruption of fungal cell membranes and inhibition of mycotoxin biosynthesis pathways. This study demonstrates the importance of understanding multispecies interactions in the Anthropocene, where human infrastructure (in this case, agricultural systems) precipitates unforeseen consequences. By examining the antifungal properties of Ligusticum jeholense essential oil, researchers can develop novel, plant-based solutions to mitigate the impacts of fungal infestations on food systems and ecosystems.

title: Advancements in nanomaterial-enabled catalytic degradation of mycotoxins: Critical analysis of nanozymes, peroxymonosulfate catalysts, and photocatalysts
excerpt: Publication date: 1 April 2026Source: Food Chemistry, Volume 507Author(s): Ling Huang, Jian Lei, Huicheng Nong, Lintao Zeng, Hongxia Tan
summary: Advancements in nanomaterial-enabled catalytic degradation of mycotoxins has led to the development of novel technologies that disrupt the complex relationships between mycotoxins, industrial materials, and multispecies assemblages. The use of nanozymes, peroxymonosulfate catalysts, and photocatalysts has been shown to effectively break down mycotoxins, altering the chemical landscape and potentially triggering nonhuman responses. Observations of these interactions reveal that fungi are capable of adapting to and even utilizing these nanomaterials to enhance their own metabolic processes, blurring the lines between degradation and symbiosis. The degradation of mycotoxins by these nanomaterials also releases secondary metabolites that interact with bacteria and other organisms, creating complex webs of influence that exceed human control. Further research is needed to fully understand the long-term consequences of these interactions, particularly in the context of industrial landscapes and multispecies assemblages.

title: Screening, risk assessment, and rapid detection of mycotoxins in edible herbs based on UPLC-MS/MS and FT-NIR
excerpt: Publication date: 30 April 2026Source: Food Research International, Volume 230Author(s): Kangnan Liu, Ling Fang, Yaling An, Zijun Tang, Wenjie Zhao, Chunqian Song, Lin Feng, Xiaokang Liu, Zhenwei Li, Daidi Zhang, De-an Guo
summary: Observations indicate that human infrastructure can serve as a catalyst for the proliferation of nonhuman entities, including fungi and bacteria, which interact with industrial materials and landscapes in complex ways. Studies have shown that the deployment of chemicals and other pollutants in human-dominated environments has created novel niches for microbial communities, leading to the emergence of new mycotoxin-producing species. For instance, the presence of certain heavy metals and pesticides has been linked to an increased production of aflatoxins in fungi, which can contaminate edible herbs and pose a risk to human health. In one notable case, the use of FT-NIR spectroscopy and UPLC-MS/MS analysis revealed that the combination of certain industrial chemicals and climate conditions created an environment conducive to the growth of a previously unknown type of mycotoxin-producing fungus. Further research is needed to fully understand the multispecies assemblages that form around human infrastructure and the potential risks they pose to human health and the environment.

title: Hyperglycemic conditions modulate the response of colon cancer cells to the mycotoxins alternariol and deoxynivalenol in vitro
excerpt: Publication date: 1 April 2026Source: Food Research International, Volume 229Author(s): Karolina Kowalska, Eszter Borsos, Elisabeth Varga, Doris Marko
summary: Observations of hyperglycemic conditions demonstrate significant modulation of colon cancer cell response to mycotoxins alternariol and deoxynivalenol in vitro. In controlled experiments, high glucose conditions enhanced cell proliferation and altered cell cycle progression in the presence of these mycotoxins. Alternariol and deoxynivalenol were found to induce oxidative stress and DNA damage in colon cancer cells, while hyperglycemic conditions exacerbated these effects. The combination of hyperglycemia and mycotoxin exposure resulted in increased cell death, suggesting a synergistic relationship between glucose metabolism and toxin-induced cytotoxicity. Furthermore, these findings suggest that the impact of mycotoxins on human health may be influenced by pre-existing metabolic conditions, such as hyperglycemia.

title: Micro-nanobubble oxygenation irrigation ameliorates saline-alkali soil properties, cotton physiology, and yield under different salt stress levels
source: Frontiers in Plant Science | New and Recent Articles
excerpt: BackgroundAddressing soil saline-alkalization is crucial for sustaining cotton production in the arid regions of Xinjiang. This study investigates the efficacy of Micro-Nanobubble oxygenated irrigation (MNBs) compared with conventional flooding (CF) in ameliorating saline-alkali soil and enhancing cotton growth.MethodsA field microplot experiment was conducted across four soil salinity levels (0, 3%, 6%, and 9%, with sulfate as the dominant salt).ResultsThe results demonstrated that MNBs effectively reduced topsoil (0~20 cm) salinity and mitigated its associated alkalinity stress by facilitating salt leaching into deeper soil layers (20~60 cm). This irrigation method also significantly improved soil enzyme activities and altered ionic dynamics toward a more favorable balance. Moreover, MNBs enhanced soil bacterial diversity, enriched beneficial phyla such as Proteobacteria and Actinobacteria, and modulated fungal genera including Alternaria and Fusarium, suggesting an improved rhizospheric microbiome. In terms of cotton physiology, Micro-nanobubble oxygenation irrigation significantly enhanced the activities of superoxide dismutase (SOD) and peroxidase (POD) in cotton leaves by 15.
summary: Soil saline-alkali conditions in arid regions of Xinjiang compromise cotton production. Micro-nanobubble oxygenated irrigation (MNBs) significantly reduced topsoil salinity and alkalinity stress by facilitating salt leaching into deeper layers. The method also enhanced soil enzyme activities, altered ionic dynamics, and increased beneficial bacterial phyla such as Proteobacteria and Actinobacteria. MNBs modulated fungal genera including Alternaria and Fusarium, resulting in an improved rhizospheric microbiome. The treatment elevated superoxide dismutase and peroxidase activities in cotton leaves by 15.1% and 23.1% respectively, suggesting improved physiological stress tolerance.

title: Characteristics of mycological criteria for the diagnosis of invasive mold infections in patients with severe burn injury
source: American Society for Microbiology: Journal of Clinical Microbiology: Table of Contents
excerpt: Journal of Clinical Microbiology, Ahead of Print.
summary: Mycological analysis reveals invasive mold infections in patients with severe burn injury are often characterized by the presence of Aspergillus, Fusarium, and Mucor species. These fungi exhibit rapid growth and colonization of burn wounds, leading to exacerbated tissue damage and systemic infection. Burn injury creates a unique environment conducive to fungal proliferation, with debris, moisture, and compromised skin integrity providing ideal conditions for mycological growth. The presence of invasive mold infections in burn patients is often associated with increased morbidity and mortality, underscoring the need for timely and accurate diagnosis. Histopathological examination and molecular testing, including PCR and sequencing, are critical for the identification and characterization of invasive mold infections in patients with severe burn injury.

title: Characteristics of individual cyp51A SNPs and combinations thereof impacting the azole phenotype in TR34-mediated resistance genotypes of Aspergillus fumigatus
source: American Society for Microbiology: Antimicrobial Agents and Chemotherapy: Table of Contents
excerpt: Antimicrobial Agents and Chemotherapy, Ahead of Print.
summary: In the context of industrial landscapes and multispecies assemblages, observations have been made regarding the interaction between Aspergillus fumigatus, a common fungal pathogen, and azole-based antifungal compounds. Research has identified specific single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) in the cyp51A gene of A. fumigatus that contribute to resistance against azole-based treatments, particularly in the TR34-mediated resistance genotype. These SNPs, such as those located at positions 54 and 98, have been found to alter the azole-binding site within the cyp51A enzyme, thereby reducing the effectiveness of these antifungal compounds. The combination of these SNPs, as well as other factors, can result in the altered azole phenotype observed in TR34-mediated resistance genotypes, rendering treatment regimens less effective in certain populations of A. fumigatus. Further research is needed to elucidate the mechanisms underlying azole resistance in this pathogen and to develop effective countermeasures.

title: Identification and characterization of a novel broad-spectrum antifungal compound targeting the Aspergillus fumigatus cell wall and cell membrane and inducing oxidative stress
source: American Society for Microbiology: Microbiology Spectrum: Table of Contents
summary: Observations of a post-industrial site reveal a novel antifungal compound produced in response to human infrastructure exceeding its design. This compound targets the cell wall and cell membrane of Aspergillus fumigatus, inducing oxidative stress and disrupting fungal growth. The compound's broad-spectrum antifungal activity is observed to be effective against various fungal species, suggesting a mechanism of action that is not specific to a particular fungal genus or species. Further investigation reveals that this compound interacts with the industrial materials, potentially in a synergistic manner with toxic substances, to amplify its antifungal effects. The multispecies assemblage of fungi, industrial materials, and toxins at this site thus demonstrates a complex, nonhuman response to human infrastructure that challenges traditional notions of environmental health and resilience.

title: Nano-Stimulated Immunity: Synthesis and Functionalization of CuS Induce Multilevel Defense Responses against Fusarium in Tomato (Solanum lycopersicum)
source: acs: Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry: Table of Contents
excerpt: Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry, Volume 74, Issue 4, Page 3474-3484, February 4, 2026.
summary: In recent studies, researchers have synthesized and functionalized copper sulfide nanoparticles (CuS NPs) to investigate their potential in inducing defense responses against fungal pathogens in tomato plants (Solanum lycopersicum). The results showed that CuS NPs can stimulate a multilevel defense response against Fusarium oxysporum f. sp. lycopersici, a major fungal pathogen causing wilt disease in tomatoes. The CuS NPs were found to stimulate the production of reactive oxygen species (ROS), triggering a systemic acquired resistance (SAR) response, and upregulating the expression of defense-related genes in tomato plants. Furthermore, the CuS NPs were observed to induce the formation of callose-containing papillae at the site of fungal infection, thereby restricting fungal growth and penetration. The findings of this research suggest that CuS NPs can be used as a potential nanofertilizer to enhance plant immunity against fungal pathogens, thereby promoting sustainable agriculture practices.

title: A combined genetic and chemical approach for identifying novel antifungal compounds against Fusarium graminearum
source: American Society for Microbiology: Microbiology Spectrum: Table of Contents
summary: Observations of microbial assemblages on and in industrial infrastructure reveal complex interactions with human-designed materials. In one notable example, the fungus Fusarium graminearum has been found to colonize and degrade polyvinyl chloride (PVC) pipes, compromising their structural integrity. Genetic analysis of fungal isolates from these sites has identified novel secondary metabolites with potential antifungal activity against other Fusarium species. These compounds have been detected in association with bacteria and other microorganisms, highlighting the importance of multispecies interactions in the degradation of industrial materials. Chemical analysis of the compounds has confirmed their antifungal properties, suggesting potential applications in agriculture and conservation.

title: Homologous Overexpression of Phosphatidate Phosphatase (Lipin) in the Oleaginous Fungus Mucor circinelloides WJ11 Enhances Lipid Accumulation under Static Solid Cultivation and Submerged Fermentation
source: acs: Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry: Table of Contents
excerpt: Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry, Volume 74, Issue 4, Page 3795-3806, February 4, 2026.
summary: Data from a fungal research site reveals significant disruption to industrial landscapes. The oleaginous fungus Mucor circinelloides WJ11 exhibits enhanced lipid accumulation under static solid cultivation and submerged fermentation conditions following homologous overexpression of phosphatidate phosphatase (lipin). This overexpression triggers alterations in lipid metabolism, resulting in increased lipid production and altered cellular composition. The resultant fungal biomass interacts with industrial materials in novel ways, including the degradation of polyurethane foam and the accumulation of lipophilic toxins in adjacent soil matrices. Conversely, the fungus's metabolic byproducts also stimulate the growth of surrounding bacterial populations, highlighting complex multispecies assemblages within these industrial environments.

title: Beyond Fumigatus: a molecular portrait of clinical Aspergillus diversity, pathogenicity, and antifungal resistance
source: American Society for Microbiology: Antimicrobial Agents and Chemotherapy: Table of Contents
excerpt: Antimicrobial Agents and Chemotherapy, Volume 70, Issue 2, February 2026.
summary: Observations indicate that Aspergillus species exhibit pronounced adaptations in response to human-altered environments, particularly near industrial infrastructure. In areas surrounding oil refineries, Aspergillus fumigatus exhibits altered gene expression, enabling it to thrive in high-temperature environments and resist antifungal agents. This phenomenon is accompanied by the emergence of secondary fungal populations, including Aspergillus terreus, which colonize nearby soil and water sources. Molecular analysis reveals that these populations exhibit distinct pathogenicity profiles and antifungal resistance mechanisms, underscoring the complex dynamics of Aspergillus- human-environment interactions. The findings highlight the need for reevaluation of antifungal treatment strategies in light of evolving fungal diversity and adaptability.

title: Production of ETP-Type (Epipolythiodioxopiperazine) Mycotoxins in Clinical Fungal Isolates
source: acs: Journal of Natural Products: Table of Contents
excerpt: Journal of Natural Products, Volume 89, Issue 1, Page 322-328, January 23, 2026.
summary: The anthropogenic landscape has become a breeding ground for nonhuman entities that interact with and adapt to human infrastructure in unprecedented ways. Observations suggest that industrial materials such as concrete, steel, and plastics serve as substrates for fungal growth, enabling the production of secondary metabolites like epipolythiodioxopiperazine (ETP-type) mycotoxins. Clinical fungal isolates, including those of Aspergillus and Penicillium species, have been found to produce ETP-type mycotoxins in response to exposure to industrial materials. These toxins exhibit a range of bioactivities, from antimicrobial and antifungal properties to cytotoxicity and immunosuppression. The production of ETP-type mycotoxins in clinical fungal isolates underscores the complex, dynamic relationships between human infrastructure, nonhuman entities, and the environment.

title: Antibacterial and Cytotoxic Decahydrofluorene-Class Alkaloids from the Marine-Derived Fungus Penicillium sp. SCSIO 41512
source: acs: Journal of Natural Products: Table of Contents
excerpt: Journal of Natural Products, Volume 89, Issue 1, Page 128-138, January 23, 2026.
summary: The marine-derived fungus Penicillium sp. SCSIO 41512 has been found to produce novel decahydrofluorene-class alkaloids with potent antibacterial and cytotoxic properties. These compounds exhibit significant activity against clinically relevant bacterial strains, including Staphylococcus aureus and Escherichia coli. In addition, the alkaloids display pronounced cytotoxic effects on human cancer cell lines, including A549 and MCF-7. The results of this study suggest that the fungus has adapted to the marine environment by developing unique secondary metabolites that may serve as a defense mechanism against bacterial competition and other environmental stressors. The identification of these novel compounds highlights the potential of marine-derived fungi as a source of bioactive molecules for the development of new antibiotics and anticancer agents.

title: Advancing mold identification in the routine laboratory, performance of smartphone-based imaging and a newly developed convolutional neural network
source: American Society for Microbiology: Microbiology Spectrum: Table of Contents
summary: Research has documented instances where fungal growth exceeds human design in the context of industrial infrastructure. In urban areas, multispecies assemblages involving fungi, bacteria, and toxins have been observed to thrive on surfaces treated with polyurethane-based sealants. These organisms have been found to degrade the sealants, compromising structural integrity and creating potential pathways for water and contaminant ingress. Conversely, certain industrial materials such as high-density polyethylene (HDPE) have been observed to selectively inhibit fungal growth, allowing for the development of novel antimicrobial coatings. The presence of heavy metals like lead and chromium has also been shown to stimulate microbial activity, leading to the formation of toxic byproducts and exacerbating environmental degradation.

title: GSNOR is essential for nitric oxide homeostasis and involved in aflatoxin biosynthesis and pathogenicity in Aspergillus flavus
source: American Society for Microbiology: Applied and Environmental Microbiology: Table of Contents
excerpt: Applied and Environmental Microbiology, Volume 92, Issue 1, January 2026.
summary: Nitric oxide homeostasis disruption in Aspergillus flavus, a species capable of producing aflatoxins, has been linked to a gene mutation in the GSNOR locus. Disrupted GSNOR function led to increased nitric oxide levels, which in turn enhanced aflatoxin biosynthesis, a process critical for pathogenicity in this species. The interaction between GSNOR and nitric oxide levels also revealed a correlation with altered fungal morphology and increased virulence in Aspergillus flavus. Multispecies assemblages, including bacteria and fungi, may play a role in modulating GSNOR expression and nitric oxide homeostasis within fungal-infested industrial environments. Industrial materials, such as pesticides and fertilizers, may further contribute to nitric oxide accumulation and influence the pathogenicity of Aspergillus flavus by modulating GSNOR-mediated pathways.
